The search results reveal a significant shift in how Gen Z approaches dating apps and hookup culture in 2024, showing a notable departure from the "Brave New World" of casual connectivity that characterized earlier dating app usage.

## Key Findings on Gen Z and Dating Apps in 2024:

### Declining App Usage
Popular dating apps like Tinder, Bumble, and Hinge are seeing major drops in user numbers. A 2024 Ofcom report showed a 16% decline in UK users across these platforms. Tinder alone lost nearly 600,000 users, with Bumble and Hinge also suffering big losses.(no content)In the U.S., a 2023 study found that nearly 80% of college students are skipping dating apps entirely.

### Rejection of Hookup Culture
Drinking and casual hookups are also down, according to recent surveys and experts. "This generation of Gen Z, 18 to 28 – it's not a hookup generation.(no content)When it comes to sexual behavior, Gen Z is surprisingly more conservative. Only 24% participate in casual romantic interactions, a significant drop from previous generations.

### App Burnout and Authenticity Issues
Forbes found in a 2024 survey that more than 75% of Gen Zers feel burnt out using dating apps like Hinge, Tinder, and Bumble because they don't feel as if they can find a genuine connection with someone despite how much time they spend on the apps.(no content)Rae Weiss, a Gen Z dating coach, said that this generation is moving away from dating apps because swiping feels "transactional, laborious and scripted." "The burnout from choice overload has left us craving authenticity and meaningful interaction, so we're seeking out organic ways to meet people offline," Weiss told Newsweek.

### Industry Response and Rebranding
Tinder — initially known as the casual sex app — is now reinventing itself for hookup-adverse Gen Z by pivoting to a focus on love.(no content)Tinder—long associated with "hookup culture"—specifically is undergoing a rebrand to appeal more to Gen Z.

### Alternative Trends
Young people, particularly women, have even gone so far as to bring back celibacy and repopularize it in the form of "boysobriety". As of July 2024, #boysober has been used in over 20.1 million posts on TikTok.(no content)Recent reports from Ofcom show that dating apps like Tinder and Bumble are losing popularity among younger people, with many turning to in-person meetings instead. A study by YouGov and Smirnoff further reveals that nearly 47% of single Gen Zers prefer meeting potential partners in everyday places, like grocery stores, rather than online.

The data suggests that rather than embracing a "Brave New World" of casual digital connectivity, Gen Z is actually moving toward more intentional, authentic relationship-seeking behaviors and rejecting the hookup-oriented culture that dating apps initially promoted.
